children.subject: A lot of times during the course you'll have to deal with homework, projects, and studying for midterms at the same time, and I found each one of these quite time consuming, especially the projects which have long documentation and are just very complicated imo, so I had a hard time even doing two of the three at the same time. The subject matter wasn't conceptually hard for me (and was interesting) and I had a good project group, but the load still threw me off overall. That was my personal experience though and I'm not sure if most people who take it feel the same way about how manageable the class is. It is heavy workload for sure though.
I never felt that 162 was high workload; most of the people I know in the class are convinced that it is pretty overhyped in difficulty/workload.
Can you explain why 162 is barely manageable? I'm taking it next semester with another tech.

history.content:
cs184_workload >= cs162_workload, but cs184_funvalue >= cs162_funvalue.

CS 184 was one of my favorite classes at Berkeley, and it convinced me that graphics is the field for me. The class portfolio you compile over the semester even landed me a cool job over the summer in graphics.

That aside, in answer to your question, the two significant obligations are projects and exams.

Projects: long and all individual (except the final project) -- potentially longer than CS 162 projects depending on how much you carried / were carried by your 162 group. You might spend vast amounts of time debugging. Or, if you're lucky, everything might work on the first try and you'll finish in a day. I was stuck for a literal month on the raytracer problem trying to figure out why my scenes were slightly dim, and it turned out to be a float precision error on 1 line out of 1000s. Every project also has a webpage writeup. You'll need to describe what you did and any problems you faced in at least basic HTML. Some people said their writeups took longer than the project itself. Sidenote, sometimes scenes take hours to render, especially if your implementation is not efficient. On the other hand, instead of simply staring at the screen and screaming internally, you could work on the writeup or do other stuff while your program chugs.

Exams: kind of tough, but they don't count for that much. They're hard to study for because the course isn't really about classic handwritten problems (making exams out of place imo). Really didn't put as much thought into them as CS 162 exams, especially since the projects are more important.

In conclusion, I highly recommend taking CS 184 in spite of the fact it probably takes even more time than CS 162. You don't often get the chance to make beautiful portfolios from your Berkeley classes, so this class is one of a kind.

I'm in 162 this semester and I've actually found the workload to be barely manageable (even given that my other two courses are light workload LEL). Initially I planned on taking 184 for this coming spring, but as it's listed as one of the heavy workload courses I'm no longer sure if I'd be able to handle the load even if I take light courses with it. That is, if I use 162 as the bar for a typical "heavy workload" course.

So at this point I'm wondering how the overall workload for 184 compares to 162?

Thanks in advance!
history.subject: CS 184 workload (compared to other courses)
